title: Thousands climb Uluru before sacred Australian site closes to tourists
text:
About 1,000 people a day are climbing Uluru, the world-famous red rock at the heart of Australia, as tourists rush for a last chance to ascend the landmark before a ban comes into force

Uluru, also known as Ayers Rock, is sacred to the Anangu nation, the traditional owners of the Unesco-listed rock, who have spent years encouraging people to not climb it out of respect. Australia will restrict access from October 26.

Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park manager Mike Misso said that the past two weeks have been the busiest it has been in more than a decade, with “near to 1,000” people making the climb every day. On two days last week, the number exceeded 1,000.

According to the park 300,000 people visited Uluru in 2015, of whom 16.2 per cent climbed the rock - roughly 135 a day.

Australian historian Dr Tim Dymond told The Telegraph that climbing Uluru despite the wishes of the Traditional Owners was “a calculated insult" to Aboriginal people.
